natural solution: First, we simplify the first part of the expression by using a common denominator of $3$. \begin{align}\left(2-\frac{4}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right)&=\left(2\cdot \frac{3}{3}-\frac{4}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right) \\ &=\left(\frac{6-4}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right) \\ &=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right).\end{align}Next we simplify the second part of the expression by using a common denominator of $4$: \begin{align}

\end{align}Finally, we can subtract the two fractions using a common denominator of $12$. \begin{align} \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)&=\left(\frac{2}{3}\cdot \frac{4}{4}\right)-\left(\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{3}\right)\\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 2 - 4/3"
and h1 : "y = 1/2 - 3/4"
shows  "x + y = 5/12"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the value of $\left(2-\frac{4}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right)$? The final Answer is \frac{5}{12}
 ### Proof
 First, we simplify the first part of the expression by using a common denominator of $3$. \begin{align}\left(2-\frac{4}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right)&=\left(2\cdot \frac{3}{3}-\frac{4}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right) \\ &=\left(\frac{6-4}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right) \\ &=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right).\end{align}Next we simplify the second part of the expression by using a common denominator of $4$: \begin{align}
 \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}\cdot \frac{2}{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right)&=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{2-3}{4}\right)\\ &=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)+\left(-\frac{1}{4}\right)\\ &=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-\left(\frac{1}{4}\right).
 \end{align}Finally, we can subtract the two fractions using a common denominator of $12$. \begin{align} \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)&=\left(\frac{2}{3}\cdot \frac{4}{4}\right)-\left(\frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{3}{3}\right)\\
 &=\frac{8-3}{12}=\boxed{\frac{5}{12}}. \end{align}
 *)

fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 2 - 4/3"
and h1 : "y = 1/2 - 3/4"
shows  "x + y = 5/12"
